results.title: Budget cuts
results.brief_description: Produced by Oxo, in association with the National Federation of Meat Traders Association, this is a demonstration of cooking, and the attractive arrangement of low-cost dishes. A butcher explains and shows various cuts of meat; emphasizes the value of cheaper cuts and how they can be used to advantage. No other credits available.

results.title: Buddhism: The Path to Enlightenment
results.brief_description: Traces the life of the Buddha from his birth as a prince through time spent as a wandering mendicant in search of a solution for life’s sorrow to his later years when he trudged the dusty paths of India preaching his ego-shattering life-redeeming message. That message is threaded throughout the film as we visit monasteries and families in two different craft communities and see how Buddhism has influenced the lives of these gentle people in southeast Asia.

results.title: Buddhism in China
results.brief_description: The rise of Buddhism in China is traced from its beginning in 4 BC. The film gives a good outline of Buddha’s philosophy and teaching, the further changes and the new sects. The film is narrated by Alexander Scourby.

results.title: Bud and Lou
results.creator_credit: Bob Balaban, Robert C Thompson and Clyde B Phillips
results.brief_description: This is a biographical made for television feature length film based on the book “Bud & Lou” by Bob Thomas which attempts to portray both the personal and professional lives of the comedic partnership of Bud Abbott and Lou Costello. It follows their career from the Burlesque days, through to broadway, radio, Hollywood and eventually television, entertaining millions along the way. They were renowned for their generosity to charitable causes and were heavily involved with the War Bond drives during WWII but each had their own personal demons to deal with including Lou’s problem with gambling and Bud’s problems with drinking and epilepsy. Harvey Korman stars as Bud Abbott, Buddy Hackett as Lou Costello, and Arte Johnson plays their loyal agent Eddie Sherman. Cast also includes Michele Lee (as Lou’s wife), Robert Reed, Donald Hotton, Harry Solin.

results.title: Buckstop
results.creator_credit: Victorian College of the Arts, School of Film and Television and Rhian Hinkley
results.brief_description: Five minutes of animation through the use of 3,000 still photographs serves as a homage to the spaghetti Western, as Buck rides into town looking for a bit of action and a parking space.

results.title: Bucklesbury farm
results.creator_credit: BBC-TV, Eileen Molony and George Inger
results.brief_description: This film shows a Britsol school six weeks after the beginning of term. An experienced teacher, new to the school, is shown introducing practical science and mathematics along lines recommended by Science 5/13: a project jointly sponsored by the Schools Council and the Nuffield Foundation. Suitable for Tertiary level students.

results.title: Bubu Films
results.brief_description: An experimental film with an imaginative use of sound. Conveys the impression of a vast shadowy world of offices and vague ghostly people who provide the forms which require your signature. Kafka-esque, impressionistic and likely to puzzle most audiences.
results.description: An experimental film with an imaginative use of sound. Conveys the impression of a vast shadowy world of offices and vague ghostly people who provide the forms which require your signature. Kafka-esque, impressionistic and likely to puzzle most audiences.

results.title: Bubbling spring = Quan shi ding dong
results.creator_credit: Shanghai Film Studios, Chen Rongxuan and Xiaohua Shi
results.brief_description:
The film revolves around the children of a newly forged community. When she was a little girl, Granny Tao used a warm heart to bridge the divide between her and her stepmother, which gave her the strength to help others learn to care for those around them. It’s not long, however, before the naughty child Xiao Hou (lit. “Little Monkey”) starts playing around on the dangerous high wall, injuring Bingbing’s arm, knocking over ink bottles and ruining the music student Xueli’s university graduation assignment.
Xueli is angry that her Granny Tao opened her home to these children and leaves home. Granny Tao becomes so distressed by these events that she falls ill, and the children go to find help. When Xueli is advised by her friends to return home to help her ailing grandma, she is stunned to find the previously raucous children diligently caring for the old woman. Xueli is moved by this to find inspiration for a graduation piece even better than her first, which she names “Spring Water Ding-Dong”.

Cultural History of the Film:
The film is a commentary on the social changes taking place within China at the time, as well as emphasising the importance of the happiness and education of a community’s children. After moving into one of the government’s newly constructed residential buildings, people from many different walks of life are faced with the joys and trials of forging a new community. China today is filled with such communities, which sprang up as a result of these government-constructed residential buildings, and the film provides a valuable glimpse into how life was at the beginning of this significant development, and how the struggles of living in such communities shaped the lives of those children, who are now the parents of today.
(2 stars - James Donald; December 15, 2010)

results.title: Bubbling over
results.brief_description: Short comedy film with singer Ethel Waters playing the part of a wife whose husband’s lazy live-in relatives make life difficult. Featuring Hamtree Harrington, the Southernaires Quartet, William Edmondson and Frank L. Wilson.

results.title: Bubbles Co-op: secondary fiction (Episode 3)
results.brief_description: This films presents two fiction films from the University of Melbourne “Bubbles Co-op” Film Festival. ine is in black and white and is technically poor; the second is shorter in length and is in colour. Suitable for Upper Primary-Upper Secondary level students. No other credits available.
